column1: 2	Sadism
column2: where violence or cruelty is practiced against others to fulfill some sort of personal or sexual gratification
column3: is in my opinion the most repugnant act a person can commit. In order to commit such an act
column4: the person must be subjugated and therefore weaker than the active participant
column5: thus compounding the act of violence. This is "evil". However
column6: if all individuals are consenting active participants
column7: I believe this to be a form of masochism
column8: albeit from the hands of another. Although this statement may seem to be an oxymoron

column10: and consequently receive it from the hands of another

column12: what two (or more) consenting adults do in private is no concern of mine.  Pick this apart at your will.  Yes
column13: some forms of masochism may exist in certain situations
column14: but this does not change the fact that in any form of consensual act
column15: violence is still taking place and this act is still horrific and evil. Therefore
column16: I stand by my belief that sadism is the most evil thing a human can indulge in.

column1: 11	* Hamas has fired over 2000 missiles into Israel in the past two weeks
column2: despite multiple ceasefire attempts by Israel to avoid bloodshed.  * Hamas' refusal to accept a ceasefire and Israel's need to protect its citizens make retaliation a necessity.   * Israel should not be held responsible for civilian casualties in Gaza when Hamas is purposely targeting civilians by firing missiles from civilian buildings.  * Hamas' disregard for civilian casualties justifies an invasion of Gaza in order to prevent further bombings.

column1: 13	Through my experience as an undergraduate Engineering student in my final year
column2: I have found that the university environment is actually uninspiring. Three years down the line you come to the realization that everyone is just passing by even here
column3: we are all just trained to become another figure for an employment statistic for the department we are in and worst of all it feels like no one actually notices. For example I came to do a final year project that was self-proposed and I really enjoyed it and didn't want it to finish but it seemed that everyone else just wanted it out of their hands showing no passion for what they created.   Now I have come to the conclusion that universities are not here to serve humanity and everyone's love for sciences or whatever subject they do but instead its just a production line for the corporate world. Even here in the UK
column4: our universities have lost their true meaning and just exist to be another product in the world's education system. We should be encouraging students to explore and create but instead it feels like universities are just fulfilling numbers.  A lot of us come out of university feeling uninspired and less prepared than when we first stepped in. It is sad but true.

column1: 34	The U.S. has one of the strongest navies in the World. We have a total of 366 military ships in commission as we speak. We have a total of 4 military ships in the area that are in danger of pirate attacks. These dangerous waters cover THOUSANDS of nautical miles. So can a mere 4 ships protect this huge expanse of sea? Not effectively. So why can't the most powerful navy in the world spare a few more ships to protect the trade routes and countries around this area? Or would we rather keep the 4 ships there and hope that no more ships get hijacked? I believe that the best option is to provide more ships in these waters in order to effectively protect the trade routes and countries around this area.  Hundreds of ships peacefully pass through the dangerous waters each day
column2: some with the intentions to provide aid to third world countries. Is it truly politically correct to allow trade routes to be dangerous and hostile? Nope.

column1: 47	There is no provision in either the Declaration of Independence or the Constitution which says that having a system of taxation is unconstitutional.  Our Founding Fathers were involved in colony governments before the Revolution
column2: in which Virginia had a house of burgesses which provided money every year to every widow and orphan
column3: as well as to use tax money to construct projects for the common good.  They also had courts to help protect their rights.  When we had our Revolution
column4: we were opposed to taxation without representation
column5: rather than taxation in general.  We never have been.   In terms of how it is enforced
column6: the Constitution says that direct taxes must be apportioned among the states according to their respective populations
column7: so it is fair and equitable.  Income taxes are constitutional provided that they are implemented in a manner which does not violate any other constitutional rights.  Thus
column8: it is possible to impose an income tax despite the fact that it is unconstitutional.  However
column9: this must be enforced according to the laws of the US Constitution.

column1: 64	I went deep sea fishing last weekend on the invitation of a friend

column11: can be immoral if the fish are being subject to suffering. However

column1: 66	We’ve got a bunch of good people in Congress who are there to serve their constituents and make a difference. They need support in terms of getting their bills passed

column1: Getting rid of term limits is not a good idea

column1: In order to have a more effective Congress

column3: there should be limits to the number of terms one can have.  This would ensure more turnover and new perspectives in the Congress.   Congress should enact term limits of no longer than two terms in both House and Senate.

column1: 96	Today a cat passed on to a busy road. It stood there and was partially injured
column2: then killed by other cars passing over it.   My sister cried out emotionally watching this poor animal suffer. I however did not feel anything. Watching a animal die will always be unpleasant

column4: it had no owners to care for it. We also show no connection to the animal; our reaction is similar to myself viewing a tree in another field.
